PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

The extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1940, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer diet
( ) Pioneer schools
( ) Pioneer churches
( ) Pioneer recreation and social life
( ) Pioneer farming experiences
( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name ...............................................................

2. Your address ......................................................................

3. Date ..............................................................................

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   Stockholm, Sweden

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Olaf Olson, builder/architect

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year).
   Summer of 1901 to file claim for homestead

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Tulsa, OK/Arizona, arriving there year of 1895. Around twenty years of age.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   Twenty years old, around that.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   To become owner of land.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    Through other people chiefly. Could not read English very well at that time.

11. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? (Any other comments).
    Harper.
PIONEER EXPERIENCE I. GENERAL INFORMATION

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Carl David Ohlson

2. Your address:

3. Date: 

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Strömsbro, Sweden

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Carl Ohlson, builder and architect

6. When did you come to Dakota Territory? (Give month and year): Summer of 1901 (Age 18)

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Dakota Territory, giving dates whenever possible.: Yuba, California, arriving there year of 1897

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you are still living in Canada). I was in my teens, etc.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: To find work and earn money

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Through other people chiefly. Learned from friend English boy and at the Town Hall)
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   With a group looking for homestead land. I believe it was called the Wright Group.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Mostly by wagon team, then some part of the way.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   At Brandon near Toba, Gordon and Cornwall.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Just six miles south and some west of Hyas, Sask.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   From cattle later years on the Swan River north of Hyas.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Working for an uncle and then as farm helper.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places there you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
Corresponded with mother in Sweden and uncle in Oklahoma.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
Edith Mary Rouse — September 27, 1906

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
My brother Simon Ohlsson

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
Brother homesteaded two quarters north of mine.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
The oats that never knew when to stop growing and sometimes froze. The long trek hauling grain to Canada to find elevators closed and then the twenty mile haul home again. The always weather in the below zero degrees at the time. Had always the shortage of enough money. Started a small sawmill because of the Reddenbach sawing slot lumber. Worked too well for a couple of years with my brother.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
Travel by horse and sleigh or went to town and back. Took time out to travel north through the Carrot River country one year. Canoeed only where land is farmed now. Winter, always hunted the allowable moose and deer.

25. When was the first car used in the community?
Possibly 1914 or 1915.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
Six miles, Hyco, Sask.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
About once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
Used the mail order catalogue almost from the first.

32. When did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, Railway stations, townships, etc.) Give in each case (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of the adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first name was given; (5) any other interesting facts.
They were two telephones, first the Government phone and then later a farmer's phone. First around 1910, late out 1913.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
Yes, after running cattle on the Swan River, decided I needed more land, sold out and moved to Alberta in 1919.
